716612f-a.folder: Bayard Street & Mott Street, Manhattan, NY
716612f-a.text:
(1)
Bayard Street, north side, east from but not including Mott Street. This view is taken during the dedication of the Gee How Oak Tong Building (A family brotherhood,) at No. 62 Bayard
Street.
September 3, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.  NNEG 3135
(2)
The same view, from a different angle.
September 3, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

721743f-a.folder: Mott Street & Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY
721743f-a.text:
Mott Street, north from Chatham Square, showing the main, thoroughfare thru that Manhattan locality known as "Chinatown". Note the ornamental iron balconies and the oriental signs with a total absence of obvious Asiatic individuals. View 2 is a
photostat copy of the original.
About 1895.
Views 1 and 2
Eugene L. Armbruster

721743f-b.folder: Mott Street & Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY
721743f-b.text:
Mott Street, north from Chatham Square, showing the main, thoroughfare thru that Manhattan locality known as "Chinatown". Note the ornamental iron balconies and the oriental signs with a total absence of obvious Asiatic individuals. View 2 is a
photostat copy of the original.
About 1895.
Views 1 and 2
Eugene L. Armbruster

721755f.folder: Mott Street & Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY
721755f.text:
Mott Street, south from a point between Bayard and Pell Streets, and across the latter to Park Street. In the background, is the R. C. Church of the Transfiguration. Note the non-oriental aspect of this locale. View 1 is the original,
View 2 a photostat positive.
About 1890
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

721758f-a.folder: Mott Street & Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY
721758f-a.text:
(1)
Mott Street, west side, north from but not including Chatham Square, to, but not including Bayard Street.
September 9, 1927.
P.L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing Mott Street, west side, at Park Street.  Also shown is the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration.
October 28, 1927.
P.L. Sperr.       Neg. # 3876


(3) The same as No. 2 showing the School adjoining the north aMe of the Church.
October 28, 1927.
P.L. Sperr.

721760f-a.text:

721764f-a.folder: Mott Street & Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY
721764f-a.text:
Mott Street, west side, north from, but not including Bayard, to and
including Canal Streets.
About 1926.
Ewing Galloway.
The Federal Writers' Project of the W.P.A. states on page 426 of its New York Panorama that No. 65 Mott Street has been occupied since 1825 and gives as the authority for that statement, the 'Plumber and Sanitary Engineer' of December 1879. This building appears in the center of this view, being the third structure from the left with fire escapes thereupon. Note that the roofing cornice has been removed. The tenements to this side of same are of the dumbbell type which originated in 1879 subsequent to the repeal in 1872 of the first tenement housing
law of 1867.
